paper.title: Micro-Habits and Midday Focus: Signals from Registry-Linked Panels
paper.subtitle: A minimal synthesis of timing regularity, small nutritional cues, and afternoon stability.

abstract.text: We examine registry-linked panels across two Nordic metros and find modest, consistent associations between micro-habits (timed snacks, brief outdoor breaks) and afternoon focus proxies. Designs are observational; causal claims are not made.

sections.heading: 1. Background
paragraphs: Minimal interventions can travel far in large populations. We focus on timing regularity and small cues—particularly light mid-morning intake—to test whether afternoon stability improves under real-world conditions.

sections.heading: 2. Data & Methods
paragraphs: We harmonize diary entries with wearable metrics (2019–2024). Core specification uses individual fixed effects; sensitivity checks exclude holiday weeks and atypical commute events. Outcomes include task completion rates and HRV smoothness.

figure.caption: Figure 1. Distribution of timing regularity indices.

sections.heading: 3. Results
paragraphs: Estimates suggest a 1–2% improvement in completion rates for respondents with consistent 10:30 cues versus matched controls. Effects attenuate among heavy caffeine users.

sections.heading: 4. Interpretation
paragraphs: Signals are small yet robust across model families. The operational cost of prompts is low, recommending pragmatic pilots before scaling.
sections.callout: “Small, boring habits beat dramatic overhauls.” — NEL Methods Desk

sections.heading: 5. Limitations
paragraphs: Observational constraints remain. Future randomized prompts could clarify pathways (sleep regularity, glycemic response, exposure to daylight).

sources: Malmö Diary Panel — Instruments & Harmonization Note 2023
